5 shows the front or peripheral side of four other columnar cells, in which
it is seen that, by the sinuosity of the partition, the apertures of any
vertical row, even when in a line with each other, open alternately into
the cells on the <u>right</u>, and on the <u>left</u>, of the septum; so that (e.g) the
passages extending backwards from the row of apertures in the
columnar cell <u>b.b'</u> Fig. 4, will debouch alternately in cells <u>a,a'</u> and <u>b,b'</u>, Fig
5, of the zone within. The same will of course be true of the pores which
open on the margin, these being nothing else than the orifices of the inter-zonular
passages just described; and the alternating direction of the passages
of which they lead may be distinguished on some parts of the specimen
figured in Plate VIII, Fig 9. This idea of the alternating direction of the
inter-zonular passages, seemed to furnish the solution of the appearances
presented in Plate IX, Fig 2; for, as the disks are seldom perfectly
flat, the section which traverses, at one part of the disk, the set
of passages running in one direction, will traverse the other set of
passages, where, by the flexure of the disk, the plane of section
is slightly altered in regard to it. All doubt, however, as to the
validity of this explanation, was removed by the examination of
the animal substance filling the vertical columns; for, as is shown
